title: Vessel of the Dancing Lords

thumbnail.alt_text: Cup shaped ceramic vessel with red glyphs and dancing figures, orange on cream ground.

artist_display:
Ah Maxam
Maya, active mid-/late 8th century
Vicinity of Naranjo, Petén region, Guatemala
description: According to ancient Maya belief, after several failed attempts the gods succeeded in populating the earth when they created humanity out of maize, the staff of life. In the Popol Vuh, a sixteenth-century epic of the K’iche’ Maya, the death and resur¬rection of the maize god was likened to seed corn that sprouted and produced new life. This vessel from the Late Classic period (600–800) depicts a Maya ruler attired as the maize god in three almost-identical panels. On his back, the ruler wears an enormous rack containing brilliant feathers, heraldic beasts, and related emblems. Just as maize plants sway to and fro, the maize god dances to the rhythm of life—often, as seen here, in the company of a dwarf. Among the Maya, dwarfs were seen as special beings with powerful spiritual connections to the earth and the interior world below. This vase refers to a rite of passage in which dwarfs assist the soul of the deceased into the domain of the dead, from which it would eventually be reborn in the royal lineage, just as maize sprouts again in the cycle of nature’s renewal. This vase of the Dancing Lords may have been painted as a funerary offering for a noblewoman with dynastic connections in the city of Naranjo, where it was made.

Everette McNear, High Culture in the Americas before 1500, exh. cat. (Arts Club Chicago, 1982), 8–9, cat. 14. Richard F. Townsend, ed., The Ancient Americas: Art from Sacred Landscapes, exh. cat. (Art Institute of Chicago, 1992), 378, cat. 127. Dorie Reents-Budet, Painting the Maya Universe: Royal Ceramics of the Classic Period, exh. cat. (Duke University Museum of Art, 1994), 319, cat. 9. James N. Wood, Treasures from The Art Institute of Chicago (Art Institute of Chicago, 2000), 30. Art Institute of Chicago, The Art Institute of Chicago: The Essential Guide, revised ed. (Art Institute of Chicago, 2003), 13. Allen J. Christenson, "Dancing in the Footsteps of the Ancestors," in Lords of Creation: The Origins of Sacred Maya Kingship, exh. cat., Virginia Fields and Dorie Reents-Budet, eds., (Los Angeles County Museum of Art, 2005), 92, no. 14. Art Institute of Chicago, Pocket Guide (Art Institute of Chicago, 2009), 3. Art Institute of Chicago, The Essential Guide (Art Institute of Chicago, 2009), 23. Richard Townsend with Elizabeth Pope Indian Art of the Americas at the Art Institute of Chicago (Art Institute of Chicago and Yale University Press, 2016), 203, 160.
exhibition_history: Rockford College Art Gallery, IL, Nov.–Dec. 1971, no cat. Princeton University, The Art Museum, Lords of the Underworld, Mar. 4–June 18, 1978, cat. 14. Arts Club of Chicago, High Culture in the Americas before 1500, Nov. 15–Dec. 31, 1982, cat. 14. Art Institute of Chicago, The Ancient Americas: Art from Sacred Landscapes, Oct. 10, 1992–Jan. 3, 1993, cat. 127; Houston, Museum of Fine Arts, Feb. 4–Apr. 18, 1993; Los Angeles County Museum of Art, June 6–Aug. 15, 1993. Durham, NC, Duke University Museum of Art, Painting of the Maya Universe, Jan. 15–Mar. 27, 1994, cat. plate 9; Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, Apr. 15–June 26, 1994; Denver Art Museum, July 15–Sept. 15, 1994; Los Angeles County Museum, Oct. 8, 1994–Jan. 8, 1995; New Haven, CT, Yale University Art Gallery, Feb. 10–Apr. 23, 1995.
provenance_text: Marianne and Robert Huber, Huber Fine Arts, Dixon, IL, by 1969 [according to correspondence from M. Huber, Feb. 14, 1986, and P. Dedrick, Rockford College, Oct. 7, 1986, copy in curatorial object file; Rockford University exh. 1971]; sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1986.
